moves.3... cxd5 4. Nf3 Bf5:
and here we are already out of book.
More common is Bd3
moves.8... Bd6 9. Re1 Nd7: Nd7 to connect Ngf6 Knights and not worry too much on Bg5
moves.10. Be3 Ne7: And here I seen Nf5 being better.
moves.11. Nbd2 h6:
prophylaxis!
Castling would lead Ng5 and Black could respond with either g6 or Ng6 and White has the initiative.
moves.14. c3 O-O 15. Qd2:
And here White develops an attack.
The Caro-Kann is defense and much of the moves require a defense against White's attack. So much how you play is responding to White's moves.
This differs greatly with the Sicilian defenses...
moves.15... Ng6:
!
Nf5 would work to I believe.
If White continues Bxh6...gxh6; Qxh6 and Black has Bf4 fork tactic 
.
moves.17. Ne5 Bxe5 18. dxe5 Nc4 19. Qd4 Ngxe5:
And here I thought it was best to capture pawn first while I can. 
Capturing the bishop empowers his rook to a good rank and can swing over to g3 or h3
moves.21. Rxe3:
And here I thought for a while...
Black has several candidate moves and they have their on purposes. 
Ng6 retreating back; Nd7 doesn't accomplish much; Nc4 can lead to exchanges with my own rook lift to Rc4; Nc6
moves.21... Nc6 22. Qg4:
It was here I notice that Queen Rank 4 has limited squares.
Queen can only go to f4!
Obviously, White is setting up Rg3 threating checkmate. Only one move away and Black has to Respond to White's idea.
moves.22... f5:
This is why I like Nc6 over Ng6.
Nc4 would lead to exchanges but I liked his rook c2 being inactive and not doing to much.
moves.23. Qe2:
??
If Queen-f4...g5?! let me know what you think maybe queenf6 better than pawn moves...
Here I saw Qe2 as a mistake.
White's Rook-c2 is hanging and I see a fork! 
Do you see it?
moves.23... Nd4:
!!
Knight fork and sacrifice and protects e6 temporarily.
moves.24. cxd4:
If Queen-h5...NxRc2; Rxe6 with my knight sort of out of play and White's Rook is in...
Queen-f6 holding the position.
